To evaluate the efficacy and safety of Baerveldt and Ahmed glaucoma drainage implants in Asian
patients
with refractory glaucoma.

The authors reviewed the insertion of 18 Ahmed glaucoma valved
implants
and 24 350 mm(2) Baerveldt glaucoma
implants
performed by a single surgeon at the Department of Ophthalmology, National University Hospital, Singapore, from _DATE_, to _DATE_. A total of 42 glaucoma drainage implants was inserted into the eyes of 41 patients. All patients had at least _POFT_ of follow up.

Intraocular
pressure
, visual acuity, and complications.

Both drainage implants achieved remarkable reductions in Intraocular Pressure; from pretreatment Intraocular Pressure of 40.1 +/ 13.8 mmHg and 43.7 +/ 9.3 mmHg to postoperative Intraocular Pressure of
17.4 +/ 6.2
and
14.9 +/ 5.5 mmHg
in the Baerveldt and Ahmed groups, respectively. A decrease in Intraocular Pressure of 56.6% and 65.9% had been achieved. Success rates were 20 _MEAS_ for Baerveldt and 12 _MEAS_ for Ahmed implants, whereas qualified success occurred in 1 _MEAS_ Baerveldt and 3 _MEAS_ Ahmed implants. Conversely, failure to control Intraocular Pressure occurred in 3 _MEAS_ Baerveldt implants and 3 _MEAS_ Ahmed implants. More than 80% of the patients had maintained or improved visual function, whereas only 4 _MEAS_ of the patients with Baerveldt implants and 2 _MEAS_ patients with Ahmed implants had loss of more than 1 Snellen line.
Both Baerveldt and Ahmed glaucoma drainage implants performed well in terms of Intraocular Pressure control, preservation of visual function, and having low complication rates.

body.title: Experience with the use of Baerveldt and Ahmed glaucoma drainage implants in an Asian population.
